lesson.name: Lesson 1.12 Teacher Guide: Writing the Equation of a Line

page.title: 1.12.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative 

The opening lesson helps students review finding the slope using the slope formula. This helps students practice substituting values for variables in formulas, which will be needed when finding equations of lines given different information. Finding the slope of a line is the first step in finding the equation of a line given two points. 

Students will write equations of lines given certain information. Students are familiar with identifying the slope and \(y\)-intercept from the equation of a line. In this lesson, they will write the equation of a line given the slope and \(y\)-intercept. It can be helpful to use graphs of the lines so students can see how the values of the slope and \(y\)-intercept affect the graph. 

Students will learn to use the point-slope form to write the equation of a line when given the slope and a point and when given two points. Students will use skills of manipulating equations as they substitute and solve. Encourage students to write out their steps and find ways to verify their answers, such as sharing with a partner or using a graphing utility or Desmos.   

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing) 

Students will be able to:

  • Choose a method to write the equation of a line based on the information given.
  • Use standard form, slope-intercept form, and point-slope form to write linear equations.

Learning Targets (Student Facing) 

  • Write an equation of the line given the slope and \( y \)-intercept.
  • Write an equation of the line given the slope and a point.
  • Write an equation of the line given two points.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS) 

TEKS Explanation of Coverage
A2(B) write linear equations in two variables in various forms, including\( y = mx + b \), \( Ax + By = C \), and \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \), given one point and the slope and given two points;
 Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson include:

Previous Vocabulary:

  • \( y \)-intercept 
  • slope-intercept form (of a linear equation)

New Vocabulary:

page.title: 1.12.1: Using the Slope Formula
page.contents:
Warm-Up (5 minutes)

The purpose of this warm-up is to help students recall finding the slope of a line. Remind students that slope is the ratio of the change in \( y \) and the change in \( x \). Substituting is an important skill in writing equations. 

Launch

Arrange students in groups of 2. Encourage students to write out each step and to use parentheses, especially when working with negative numbers. 

Student-Facing Statement

Use the slope formula, \( m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \), to find the slope of the line through the given points.

1. \( (1, -2) \) and \( (3, 4) \)
2. \( (-2, -3) \) and \( (-7, 4) \)

Student Response

1. \( m= 3 \)

First, name \( (1, −2) \) as point 1 and \( (3, 4) \) as point 2.

\( (x_1, y_1) \) and \( (x_2, y_2) \)

\( (1,−2) \) and \( (3, 4) \)

Use the slope formula.

\( m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \)

Substitute the values: \( y_2 = 4, y_1 = -2, x_2 = 3, x_1 = 1 \).

\( m=\frac{4-(-2)}{3-(1)} \)

Simplify.

\( m=\frac{6}{2} \)

\( m= 3 \)

2. \( m= -\frac{7}{5} \)

First, name \( (−2, −3) \) as point 1 and \( (−7, 4) \) as point 2.

\( (x_1, y_1) \) and \( (x_2, y_2) \)

\( (−2,−3)\) and \( (−7, 4) \)

Use the slope formula.

\( m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \)

Substitute the values: \( y_2 = 4, y_1 = −3, x_2 = −7, x_1 = −2 \).

\( m= \frac{4-(-3)}{-7-(-2)} \)

Simplify.

\( m= \frac{7}{-5} \)

\( m= -\frac{7}{5} \)

Anticipated Misconceptions

Some students may be confused by the subscripts. Point out that the notation helps make sure that you are matching the correct \( x \)-value with the corresponding \( y \)-value. Demonstrate that you can name either point as \( (x_1, y_1) \) by having students find the slope by naming \( (-7, 4) \) as \( (x_1, y_1) \) and \( (-2,-3) \) as \( (x_2, y_2) \).   

Activity Synthesis

Ask students to share their methods for finding the slope. 

Discuss with students:

  • “How do you decide which point to use for \( (x_1, y_1) \) and \( (x_2, y_2) \)?” (Answers vary.)
  • “Does it matter which point you choose for \( (x_1, y_1) \) and \( (x_2, y_2) \)?” (No.)
  • “How can you make sure you use the correct corresponding \( x \) for each \( y \)?” (Answers vary: Possible answer: Always start with the \( y \) in the second point, so start with \( x \) in the second point).

page.title: 1.12.2: Writing an Equation Given the Slope and y-Intercept
page.contents:
Activity (10 minutes)

We can  determine the slope and intercept of a line if the equation is written in slope-intercept form, \( y = mx + b \), where \(m\) is the slope and \( b \) is the \( y \)-intercept. Now we will do the reverse—we will start with the slope and \(y\)-intercept and use them to write the equation of the line.

Launch

Students found the slope of a line using the formula. Use a graph to demonstrate that the slope of the line is the ratio of rise over run, change in \( y \) over change in \( x \). Ask students: 

  • How can you identify the \( y \)-intercept from a graph? (It is the point where the line crosses the \( y \)-axis.) 
  • What is the value of \( x \) where the line crosses the \( y \)-axis? (0)  

Allow students to use a graphing calculator or Desmos to check their answers where appropriate. Students develop a connection between the equation of a line and the features of its graph.

Student-Facing Statement

Recall that the slope-intercept form of the equation of a line is \( y = mx+b \), where \(m\) is the slope and \(b\) is the \( y \)-intercept. The \( y \)-intercept is the point where the graph crosses the \( y \)-axis. For \( y \)-intercept \( b \), the coordinates of the point are \( (0, b) \).

1. For each of the three equations below, tell the slope, \( m \), and \( y \)-intercept, \( b \).

a. \( y=2x +5 \)
b. \( y = -3x + 2 \)
c. \( y=-\frac{1}{5}x-1 \)

2. Here are some slopes and \( y \)-intercepts. Tell which equation matches each set of slopes and \( y \)-intercepts.

a. slope: \( -2 \), \( y \)-intercept: \( 3 \)
b. slope: \( 3 \), \( y \)-intercept: \( -2 \)
c. slope: \( 2 \), \( y \)-intercept: \( -3 \)
d. slope: \( \frac{1}{2}\), \( y \)-intercept: \( -3 \)

Equations: 

\( y = 2x - 3 \)
\( y = -2x +3 \)
\( y = \frac{1}{2}x - 3 \)
\( y = 3x - 2 \)

3. Write the equation of a line with the following slope and \( y \)-intercept in slope-intercept form.

a. slope \( −9 \) and \( y \)-intercept \( (0, −4) \)
b. slope \( \frac{2}{5} \) and \( y \)-intercept \( (0, 4) \)  

Student Response

1. Answers:

a. \( m=2, b = 5 \)
b. \( m = -3, b =2 \)
c. \( m = -\frac{1}{5}, b = -1 \)

2. Answers:

a. \( y = -2x +3 \)
b. \( y = 3x - 2 \)
c. \( y = 2x - 3 \)
d. \( y = -\frac{1}{2}x - 3 \)

3. Answers:

a. \( y = −9x − 4 \)

Here’s how to write the equation of a line given the slope and \( y \)-intercept.

First, name the slope.
\( m = −9 \)

Then, name the \( y \)-intercept.
\( y \)-intercept \( (0, −4) \)

Write the slope-intercept form of the equation of a line.
\( y = mx + b \)

Substitute the values into \( y = mx + b \).
\( y = −9x + (−4) \)

Write the equation.
\( y = −9x − 4 \)

b. \( y = \frac{2}{5}x + 4 \)

Here’s how to write the equation of a line given the slope and \( y \)-intercept.

First, name the slope.
\( m = \frac{2}{5} \)

Then, name the \( y \)-intercept.
\( y \)-intercept \( (0, 4) \)

Write the slope-intercept form of the equation of a line.
\( y = mx + b \)

Substitute the values into \( y = mx + b \).
\( y = \frac{2}{5}x + 4 \)

Write the equation.
\( y = \frac{2}{5}x + 4 \)

Activity Synthesis

The slope-intercept form of the equation of a line is the most commonly used form. You can identify the slope and the \( y \)-intercept, and it is the form used to graph the line using a graphing calculator. The equation \( y=mx+b \) may look to some students like there are 4 variables. Point out the \( m \) and \( b \) are numbers that you are given to substitute into the equation. The value of \( m \) is the coefficient of \( x \), and the value of \( b \) is the constant in the equation of the line.

Students may be confused about the value of \( b \) as the \( y \)-intercept. Elicit that the \( y \)-intercept is the point where the graph crosses the \( y \)-axis. The \( x \)-value of the \( y \)-intercept is zero. In the slope-intercept form, the \( b \) represents the \(y\)-value of the \( y \)-intercept. Sometimes the \( y \)-intercept is identified as just the \( y \)-value. For example, the \( y \)-intercept is 2 really means the \( y \)-intercept is \( (0, 2) \). To write the equation of a line in slope-intercept form, substitute 2 for \( b \): \( y=mx+2 \). 

It may help students to practice writing equations with the same slope and different \(y\)-intercepts. For example, have students write the equation of a line with slope 2 and \( y \)-intercept \( (0, 4) \) \( (y=2x+4) \); slope 2 and \( y \)-intercept \( (0, -1) \) \( (y=2x-1) \); slope 2 and \( y \)-intercept \((0, 3)\) \( (y=2x+3) \). Then have students write the equation of a line with different slopes and the same \( y \)-intercept. For example, have students write the equation of a line with slope 4 and \( y \)-intercept 5; slope \( \frac{2}{3} \) and \( y \)-intercept 5; slope \( -\frac{1}{2} \) and \( y \)-intercept 5. 

1.12.2: Self Check 

Following the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:
Write the equation of a line in slope-intercept form with the slope of \( \frac{3}{4} \) and a \( y \)-intercept of \( -2 \).
Answers Feedback
\( y = - \frac{3}{4} x - 2 \) That’s correct! Check yourself: The slope-intercept form is \( y=mx+b \). The slope is \( m= -\frac{3}{4} \), and the \(y\)-intercept is \( b=-2 \), so this is the correct equation.
\( y = -\frac{3}{4} x + 2 \) Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The slope-intercept form of the equation of a line is \( y=mx+b \). Be careful with the signs during substitution. The answer is \( y = - \frac{3}{4} x - 2 \).
\( 3x + 4y =-8 \) Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Make sure to use the correct form. This is standard form, not slope-intercept form. The answer is \( y = - \frac{3}{4} x - 2 \).
\( y = \frac{3}{4} x -2 \) Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The slope-intercept form for the equation of a line is \( y=mx+b \). Be careful with the signs during substitution. The answer is \( y = - \frac{3}{4} x - 2 \).


1.12.2: Additional Resources 

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Write Equations Given a Slope and \( y \)-Intercept

We can determine the slope and intercept of a line if the equation is written in slope-intercept form, \( y=mx+b \). Now we will do the reverse—we will start with the slope and \( y \)-intercept and use them to find the equation of the line.

Example: 

Find the equation of a line with slope \( −1 \) and \( y \)-intercept \( (0,−3) \).

Solution: 

Name the slope.

\( m = -1 \)

Name the \( y \)-intercept.

\( b = -3 \)

Substitute the values into \( y = mx + b \).

\( y = -1x + -3 \) 
\( y = -x-3 \)


The same information can be picked up from a graph of a line. 

Example: 

Find the equation of the line shown in the graph.

 Solution:

Find the slope by counting the rise and run.

\( m=\frac{rise}{run} \) 
From \( (0, -4) \) to \( (3,-2) \), the slope is \( m = \frac{2}{3} \).

Find the \( y \)-intercept.

\( y \)-intercept \( (0, -4) \)
\( b = -4 \)

Substitute the values into \( y = mx + b \).

\( y = mx +b \)
\( y = \frac{2}{3} x - 4 \)

Try It: Write Equations Given a Slope and \( y \)-Intercept

Write the equation of the line graphed below in slope-intercept form:


Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to write the equation of the line in slope-intercept form:

Find the slope by counting the rise and run.

\( m=\frac{rise}{run} \) 
From \( (0, 1) \) to \( (5, 4) \), the slope is \( m = \frac{4}{5} \).

Find the \( y \)-intercept.

\( y \)-intercept \( (0, 1) \)
\( b = 1 \)

Substitute the values into \( y = mx + b\).

\( y = mx +b \)
\( y = \frac{3}{5} x + 1 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 1.12.3: Writing an Equation Given the Slope and a Point
page.contents:
Activity (18  minutes)

Students wrote the equation of a line in slope-intercept form given the slope and the \( y \)-intercept. In this lesson, students will find the equation of a line given the slope and a point that is not the \( y \)-intercept. Point-slope form is new to students. Deriving the formula from the formula for slope can help students see that there is a connection to the slope, which they already know how to find. Allow students to use a graphing calculator or Desmos where appropriate to check their answers. Point out to students that most graphing calculators require the equations to be in slope-intercept form to graph them. 

Launch

Have students work in pairs. When deriving the formula, watch that students do not distribute \( m \) to the \( x \)-variables. While students are working, check to see that they are substituting the correct values into the equation. Remind students they can graph a line given a point and the slope by plotting the given point and using the rise over run to find another point. Remind them the rise is the change in \(y\) and the run is the change in \( x \). For example, a slope of 3 can be written as \( \frac{3}{1} \): the rise is 3, and the run is 1.   

Student-Facing Statement

What if the point you are given isn’t a \( y \)-intercept? Point-slope is a great form to use when you are given the slope and any point. 

First, work to derive the point-slope formula by completing the following steps:

Start with the slope formula as \( m= \frac{y-y_1}{x-x_1} \).

Step 1: Multiply both sides of the equation by \( x - x_1 \).

Step 2: Simplify.

Step 3: Rewrite the equation with the \(y\) terms on the left.

With your partner, you will find the equation of the line in point-slope form that goes through the point \( (3, 4) \) and has a slope of 2 by answering the following questions.

1. Use the point and slope to graph the line on a coordinate plane using a graphing calculator or Desmos.

2. Write the equation for point-slope form.

3. Name the point \( (x_1, y_1) \) and the slope, \( m \).

4. Substitute the point and slope into the point-slope form.

5. Now, with your partner, each solve for \(y\) to write the equation in slope-intercept form. Compare your answers for any possible errors. Come to an agreement on your equation.

Student Response

Step 1: \( m(x-x_1)=\left(\frac{y-y_1}{x-x_1}\right)(x-x_1) \)

Step 2: \( m(x-x_1)=y-y_1 \)

Step 3: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \)

Sample answer:

2. \( y-y_1=m(x-x_1) \)

3. \( x_1=3,\ y_1=4,\ m =2 \)

4. \( y -4 =2(x-3) \)

5. \( y = 2x - 2 \)

Activity Synthesis

Students may get a little confused because \(x\) and \(y\) appear twice in the formula. Point out that the \(x\) and \(y\) with the subscript indicate the \(x\) and \(y\) values that are given to you. The \(x\) and \(y\) with the subscript are replaced by the known values in the given point. Point out to students that writing the equation in the slope-intercept form allows them to graph the equation using a graphing calculator.

1.12.3: Self Check 

Following the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:
Which equation represents the slope-intercept form of the equation of a line with slope \( m = -\frac{3}{4} \) that contains the point \( (4, -7) \)?
Answers Feedback
\( y =-\frac{3}{4}x - 4  \) That’s correct! Check yourself:
Substitute \(-\frac{3}{4} \) for \( m\), 4 for \( x_1 \), and \( −7 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).
Simplify the equation \( y - (-7) = -\frac{3}{4}(x - 4) \) to get \( y + 7 = -\frac{3}{4}x + 3 \). 
\( y =-\frac{3}{4}x - 1\frac{1}{4} \) Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Remember the \( x \)-coordinate is the first coordinate and the \( y \)-coordinate is the second coordinate. 

Substitute \(-\frac{3}{4} \) for \( m\), 4 for \( x_1 \), and \( −7 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).
Simplify the equation \( y - (-7) = -\frac{3}{4}(x - 4) \) to get \( y + 7 = -\frac{3}{4}x + 3 \).
The answer is \( y = -\frac{3}{4}x - 4 \).
\( y =-\frac{3}{4}x − 11 \) Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:
Substitute \(-\frac{3}{4} \) for \( m\), 4 for \( x_1 \), and \( -7 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).
Simplify the equation \( y - (-7) = -\frac{3}{4}(x - 4) \).
Be careful when using the distributive property to multiply \( -\frac{3}{4} \) by \( x \) and by \( 4 \).
The equation simplifies to \( y + 7 = -\frac{3}{4}x + 3 \).
The answer is \( y =-\frac{3}{4}x - 4 \).
\( y =-\frac{3}{4}x +10  \) Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:
Substitute \(-\frac{3}{4} \) for \( m\), 4 for \( x_1 \), and \( -7 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).
Simplify the equation \( y - (-7) = -\frac{3}{4}(x - 4) \). Watch the signs when simplifying. The equation simplifies to \( y + 7 = -\frac{3}{4}x + 3 \).
The answer is \( y =-\frac{3}{4}x - 4 \).


1.12.3: Additional Resources 

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Write the Equation of a Line Given the Slope and a Point

Writing an equation using the slope-intercept form works well when you are given the slope and \(y\)-intercept. If you are given the slope and another point that is not the \(y\)-intercept, we need another form of the equation of a line. 

The point-slope form of an equation of a line can be derived from the formula for slope. Suppose you have a line that has slope \(m\) and that contains some specific point \( (x_1, y_1) \) as point 1 and some other point, \( (x, y) \), as point 2. You can write the slope of this line and then change it to a different form.

The point-slope form of an equation of a line with slope \(m\) and containing the point \( (x_1, y_1) \) is: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). You can use this form to find the equation of a line when you are given the slope and a point.

Example 1 

Write the equation of a line with slope \( m = -\frac{1}{3} \) that contains the point \( (6, -4) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form. 

Step 1: Identify the slope. 
The slope is given.

\( m = \frac{1}{3} \)

Step 2: Identify the point.
The point is given.

\( (x_1, y_1) \)
\( (6, -4) \)

Step 3: Substitute the values into the point-slope form, \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). Simplify.

\( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \)
\( y - (-4) = \frac{1}{3}(x - 6) \)
\( y + 4 = \frac{1}{3}x + 2 \)

Step 4: Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

\( y = \frac{1}{3}x -2 \)


To find an equation of a line given the slope and a point, follow these steps:

Step 1:

Identify the slope.

Step 2:

Identify the point.

Step 3:

Substitute the values into the point-slope form, \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).

Step 4:

Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

Example 2 

Find the equation of a horizontal line that contains the point \( (–2, –6) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

Step 1: Identify the slope. Every horizontal line has slope 0.

\( m = 0 \)

Step 2: Identify the point.

\( (x_1, y_1) \)
\( (–2, –6) \)

Step 3: Substitute the values into the point-slope form, \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). Simplify.

\( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \)
\( y - (-6) = 0(x - (-2)) \)
\( y + 6 = 0 \)

Step 4: Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

\( y = -6 \)
\( y = 0x - 6 \)


Try It: Writing the Equation of a Line Given the Slope and Point

Write the equation of a line with slope \( m = -\frac{2}{5} \) that contains the point \( (10, −5) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form. 

Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution 

Here is how to write the equation of a line with a point and slope using a general strategy.

Step 1: Identify the slope.

\( m = -\frac{2}{5}\) 

Step 2: Identify the point.

\( (x_1, y_1) \)
\( (10, -5) \)

Step 3: Substitute the values into the point-slope form, \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). Simplify.

\( y - y_1 = m(x -x_1) \)
\( y - (-5) = (x - 10) \)
\( y + 5 = x + 4 \)

Step 4: Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

\( y = x - 1 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 1.12.4: Writing an Equation Given Two Points
page.contents:
Activity (18 minutes)

This lesson combines the skills from the first activity: using the slope formula and finding the equation of a line given a point and the slope. First, students use the slope formula to find the slope. Then, they use the point-slope formula to write the equation. Encourage students to write out an example in a notebook or on paper or notecards. The graph gives students a visual representation of slope, change in \( y \), \( {\ y}_2-y_1 \) over change in \( x \), \( x_2-x_1 \).  

Launch

Consider having student work in pairs. After the self-check, suggest students graph the line with a graphing calculator or Desmos to see that the line goes through the two points. Have them check the \(y\)-intercept also.

Student-Facing Statement

Answer the following questions.

1. Use the graph below to pick two points and find the slope between the two points.


2. Use your two points in the slope formula to confirm the slope is correct.

3. Using the slope and a point, write your equation in point-slope form.

4. Now write your equation in slope-intercept form.

5. Look at your equation and the original graph. What do you notice? How can you use a graph to check your equation?

Student Response

1. The slope of the line is \( - \frac{1}{3} \).

2. Sample Answer: \( m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}=\frac{1-3}{4-(-2)}=\frac{-2}{6}=-\frac{1}{3} \)

3. Sample Answer:

\( m = - \frac{1}{3} \) and \( (4, 1) \)

\( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \) becomes: \( y - 1 = - \frac{1}{3} (x - 4) \)

4. \( y =- \frac{1}{3}x + \frac{7}{3} \)

5. Sample answer: The \( y \)-intercept of the graph is \( \frac{7}{3} \), and the slope is \( - \frac{1}{3} \).

Activity Synthesis

There are two important concepts in this lesson. Help students understand the relationship between the points on a line, the slope of the line, and the equation of the line. Students may be able to understand the slope-intercept form of the equation of the line because they can look at the graph of the line and see the \(y\)-intercept, and they can count out the slope using rise over run. Students may not see the relationship between the points on the line and the point-slope form of the equation. One way to help students see is to give them 4 equations in point-slope form: A: \(y-1=2(x+1)\); B: \(y-5=2(x-1)\); C: \(y-5=-2(x-1)\); D: \(y-1=-2(x+1)\).

Here are some things to discuss:

  • “Which equations go through the same points? Name the points.” (A and D go through \((-1, 1)\); B and C go through \((1, 5)\).)
  • “Which equations have the same slope? Name the slope.” (A and B have slope 2. C and D have slope \(-2\).)
  • “Do lines A and B represent the same line? Explain how you know.” (Yes; A and B represent the line \(y=2x+3\).) 
  • “Do lines C and D represent the same line? Explain how you know.” (No; Line C represents the line \(y-2x+7\). Line D represents the line \(y=-2x-1\). They are not the same line.) 

If there is time, have students graph the lines to check the responses.

1.12.4: Self Check 

Following the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:
Which equation represents the slope-intercept form of the equation of a line containing the points \( (–2, –4) \) and \( (1, –3) \)?
Answers Feedback
\( y =\frac{1}{3}x - 3\frac{1}{3} \) That’s correct! Check yourself:

First, find the slope by substituting \( –3 \) for \( y_2 \), \( –4 \) for \( y_1 \), 1 for \( x_2 \), and \( –2 \) for \( x_1 \) in the slope formula: \( m= \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \). The slope is \( m= \frac{-3-(-4)}{1-(-2)} = \frac{1}{3} \). 

Substitute the slope and the coordinates of the points into the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).

Simplify the equation \( y - (-3) = \frac{1}{3}(x - 1) \) to get \( y + 3 = \frac{1}{3}x - \frac{1}{3} \). 
\( y = \frac{1}{3}x - 2\frac{1}{3} \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 

First find the slope by substituting \( –3 \) for \( y_2 \), \( –4 \) for \( y_1 \), 1 for \( x_2 \), and \( –2 \) for \( x_1 \) in the slope formula: \( m= \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \). The slope is \( m= \frac{-3-(-4)}{1-(-2)} = \frac{1}{3} \). 

Substitute the slope and the coordinates of the points into the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). You can use the coordinates from either point. Make sure you choose the \( x \) and \( y \) value from the same point. 

Simplify the equation \( y - (-3) = \frac{1}{3}(x - 1) \) to get \( y + 3 = \frac{1}{3}x - \frac{1}{3} \). The answer is \( y =\frac{1}{3}x - 3\frac{1}{3} \).
\( y = 7x + 10 \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:  

First find the slope by substituting \( –3 \) for \( y_2 \), \( –4 \) for \( y_1 \), 1 for \( x_2 \), and \( –2 \) for \( x_1 \) in the slope formula: \( m= \frac{y2-y1}{x2-x1} \). The slope is \( m= \frac{-3-(-4)}{1-(-2)} = \frac{1}{3} \). 

Substitute the slope and the coordinates of the points into the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - (-3) = \frac{1}{3}(x - 1) \) to get \( y + 3 = \frac{1}{3}x - \frac{1}{3} \). The answer is \( y =\frac{1}{3}x - 3\frac{1}{3} \).
\( y = 3x - 6 \)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 

Remember, the \(x\)-coordinate is the first coordinate, and the \(y\)-coordinate is the second coordinate. 

The slope is the change in \(y\) over the change in \(x\). Find the slope by substituting \( –3 \) for \( y_2 \), \( –4 \) for \( y_1 \), 1 for \( x_2 \), and \( –2 \) for \( x_1 \) in the slope formula: \( m= \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \). The slope is \( m= \frac{-3-(-4)}{1-(-2)} = \frac{1}{3} \). 

Substitute the slope and the coordinates of the points into the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - (-3) = \frac{1}{3}(x - 1) \) to get \( y + 3 = \frac{1}{3}x - \frac{1}{3} \). The answer is \( y =\frac{1}{3}x - 3\frac{1}{3} \).


1.12.4: Additional Resources 

Find an Equation of the Line Given Two Points

So far, you have two options for finding an equation of a line: slope-intercept or point-slope. When you start with two points, it makes more sense to use the point-slope form.

But then you need the slope. You can find the slope with just two points and then use it and one of the given points to find the equation.

For example, 

Write the equation of a line that contains the points \( (–3, –1) \) and \( (2, –2) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

Step 1: Find the slope using the given points.

Find the slope of the line through \( (–3, –1) \) and \( (2, –2) \).

\( m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 -x_1} \) 
\( m = \frac{-2 - (-1)}{2-(-3)} \) 
\( m = \frac{-1}{5} \)
\( m = - \frac{1}{5} \)

Step 2: Choose one point.

Choose either point.

\( (x_1, y_1) \)
\( (2, –2) \)

Step 3: Substitute the values into the point-slope form, \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify.

\( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \)
\( y - (-2) = \frac{1}{5}(x - 2) \)
\( y + 2 = \frac{1}{5}x + \frac{2}{5} \)

Step 4: Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

  

\( y = \frac{1}{5}x - \frac{8}{5} \)


Use this table for easy reference to find an equation of a line given two points.

Step 1 

Find the slope using the given points. 
\( m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 -x_1} \) 

Step 2

Choose one point.

Step 3

Substitute the values into the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).

Step 4

Write the equation in slope-intercept form.


To find an equation of a line given the slope and a point, follow these steps:

Step 1

Identify the slope.

Step 2

Identify the point.

Step 3

Substitute the values into the point-slope form, \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).

Step 4

Write the equation in slope-intercept form.


Try It: Writing the Equation of a Line Given the Slope and Point

Write the equation of a line that contains the points \( (–3, 5) \) and \( (–3, 4) \).

Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to find an equation of a line that contains the points \( (–3, 5) \) and \( (–3, 4) \).

Again, the first step will be to find the slope.

1. Find the slope of the line through \( (–3, 5) \) and \( (–3, 4) \).

2. \( m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 -x_1} \) 

3. \( m = \frac{4-5}{-3-(-3)} \) 

4. \( m = \frac{-1}{0} \)

A line with undefined slope is a vertical line. Both given points have an \( x \)-coordinate of \( –3 \). So, the equation of the line is \( x = -3 \). There is no \( y \), so the equation cannot be written in slope-intercept form.


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 1.12.5: Choosing a Method to Write an Equation
page.contents:
Cool-Down (5 minutes)

Launch

In this activity, students examine the point-slope form of a line. Students work in groups of 2. Each group is given 8 slips of paper. Two of the slips have a pair of points listed. Each partner takes one of the Points slips. The rest of the slips have equations, written in point-slope form. The goal for students is to find which of the equations represent an equation of a line that goes through the points on their slip. There are 2 equations that do not match either of the given points.  

Make a copy of the Points/Equation Activity slips paper, one for each group. Cut out each sheet into 8 slips. Distribute the set of 8 slips to each group. Students start by each partner choosing one of the two Points slips in the set. They can set the Equation slips aside for the second part of the activity. You may want to start with a brief review of the forms of equations and when to use them.

Student-Facing Statement

You have seen that you can use either the slope-intercept form or the point-slope form to find an equation of a line. Which form you use will depend on the information you are given.

The table can be used as a reference.

To Write an Equation of a Line

If given:

Use:

Form:

Slope and \(y\)-intercept

slope-intercept

\( y = mx + b \)

Slope and a point

point-slope

\( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \)

Two points

point-slope

\( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \)

1. Each partner should find a slip labeled “Points.” Place the remaining equation slips in a pile face down to be used in the second step.

Find the slope of the line containing the points on your slip.

Take turns sharing with your partner the slope of your line and the method used to find the slope.

2. Partners take turns choosing slips from the pile to see if the equation on the slip represents the line formed by the points on their Points slip. 

  • One partner chooses an Equation slip from the pile. Decide if the equation matches your Points slip. If it matches, explain to your partner how you know it is a match. If it is not a match, give the slip to your partner to verify it is a match to their Points card. If you disagree, discuss your thinking and work to reach an agreement.
  • Take turns choosing slips from the pile until all the slips are gone. Each partner should end with a total of 4 slips.

3. Is identifying the slope enough to match your set of points to an equation?



Student Response

1. Answers will vary, but you will use the point-slope form to find the line \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \) given the two points on your slip.

2. Answers may vary. Compare your answer to the samples.

Solution: Points: \( (3, 4) \) and \( (6, 2) \): \( y - 2 = -12(x - 6) \); \( y - 4 = -12(x - 3) \)

Points: \( (3, 4) \) and \( (6, 2) \): \( y - 2 = 23(x - 6) \); \( y + 4 = 23(x + 3) \)

Equations with no match: \( y + 4 = -12(x + 3) \); \( y - 4 = 23(x - 3) \)

3. The slope is not enough to match the set of points to an equation because lines can have the same slope and go through different points.

page.title: 1.12.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
The focus of the lesson is methods for writing equations of a line. The method you use is based on the information you are given.

The table can be used as a reference to write the equation of a line, based on the information given.

To Write an Equation of a Line
If given: Use: Form: Steps
Slope and \( y \)-intercept slope-intercept \( y = mx + b \) Substitute the slope for \(m\) and the \(y\)-intercept for \( b \) into the slope-intercept form.
Slope and a point point-slope \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \) Substitute the slope for \(m\), the \(x\)-value of the point for \( x_1 \), and the \(y\)-value of the point for \( y_1 \).
Two points point-slope \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \) Use the slope formula \( m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \) to find the slope of the line. Then, substitute the slope for \(m\), the \( x \)-value of one of the points for \( x_1 \), and the \(y\)-value of one of the point for \( y_1 \).


Encourage students to check their equations by using a graphing calculator or Desmos. Tell students to look at the graph to make sure it goes through the given points. 

To continue to the student-facing version of this lesson, select “Lesson 1.12: Writing the Equation of a Line” below.

page.title: 1.12.6: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

In questions 1–3, find the equation of a line with given slope and \( y \)-intercept. Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

1. slope 3 and \( y \)-intercept \( ( 0,5) \)

  1. \(y=5x+3\)
  2. \(y=3x+0\)
  3. \(y=3x+5\)
  4. \(y=0x+3\)

ANSWER: \( y=3x+5 \)

2. slope \(−3 \) and \( y \)-intercept \( (0,−1)\)

  1. \(y=-x-3\)
  2. \(y=-3x-1\)
  3. \(y=-x+0\)
  4. \(y=0x-3\)

ANSWER: \( y=-3x-1 \)


In questions 3-4 choose the slope-intercept form of the equation of the line, shown in each graph.


3. 


  1. \(y=-3x+5\)
  2. \(y=5x-3\)
  3. \(y=-5x+3\)
  4. \(y=3x-5\)

4. 


  1. \(y=-2x+4\)
  2. \(y=2x+4\)
  3. \(y=½ x -4\)
  4. \(y=½ x+2\)

ANSWER: \( y=-2x+4 \)

5. Choose the equation of a line with the given slope and containing the given point that best represents the line in slope-intercept form.

 \( m= -7 \), point \( (−1,−3) \)

  1. \(y=-7x-1\)
  2. \(y=-7x-3\)
  3. \(y=-3x+10\)
  4. \(y=-7x-10\)

ANSWER: \( y=-7x-10 \)

 

6. Choose the equation of a line containing the given points that best represents the line in slope-intercept form.

  1. \(y=-\frac72x-3\)
  2. \(y=\frac72x+4\)
  3. \(y=-\frac27x+4\)
  4. \(y=-\frac72x+4\)
ANSWER: \(y=-\frac72x+4\)

7. Choose the equation of a line containing the given points that best represents the line in slope-intercept form.

(3,−4) and (5,−4)

  1. \(y=-4\)
  2. \(y=0\)
  3. \(x=2\)
  4. \(x=-2\)
ANSWER:  \(y=-4\)
